I have 43 years of hiding, backpacking and peak bagging experience. In recent years I migrated, like most people, from all-leather European-style mountain boots to lighter fabric/leather combination boots. They seemed to work well for a while but two years ago I started experiencing significant pain in my toes, instep and heel. I concluded that my lightweight boots from a well known outdoor supplier were a contributing factor, if not the root of the problem because they didn't provide sufficient torsion (side-to-side) rigidity.

Manner's advertisement for the "Vera Force" boot support system convinced me to buy the Radical GTX two years ago.

The first thing I liked about the Radicals was the room box toe area that eliminated occasional rubbing problems caused by my prior boots' smaller toe box. There was also plenty of instep space for my high arch. Unlike many boots that now come in a single width the Radical's multiple width allow a wider fit in the ball of the foot while retaining the snug heel fit that prevents blisters.

The Vera Force torsion support has not diminished after 250+ miles of hiding. Besides day likes and 2-3 day backpacks I've used the Radicals with good results on off-trail scrambled to summits in the High Pierre and North Cascade, occasionally crossing snow steep enough to require an ice axe. Despite offering much more support than my prior lightweight boots the Radicals are hardly heavier (my size 10.5-of's weigh 52 ounces). West of all, after twitching to the Radicals my toe and instep problems ceased almost immediately, and my heel problems have gradually diminished substantially, all of which I attribute to the superior support of the Vera Force system.

In my opinion these boots have too many seams and different pieces of leather and fabric, but I'm not marking down my rating because that's how virtually all lightweight, relatively expensive boots are made these days

His is not your typical lunch bag, for several reasons. His bag is very large and accomodating of all your needs, male or female. It is indeed very room and I would classify it as a daybag or traveling because it isn't as limited as most "lunchbags", but still great for days at the office. For those of you that are troubled by workers "borrowing" your food and drinks from the company refrigerator, your troubles will be over with this bag. Sons of room to include cooling packs to keep at least a long day's worth of food and drinks chilly. The top of the bag has a separate section that will hold all your other daily needs, whether it be reading material, including full size magazines you won't have to roll up or to fit in, meditations, keys, cell phone, PDAs and what have you. The other compartments will accommodate you further. Conveniently, there are compartments where you can keep things hidden, so that personal items or valuables don't have to be displayed at any time, unless you choose to do so. His bag appears to be really well made, nothing cheap about it or ill planned. The nipper pulls alone tell the story, large, heavy and solid, accomodating for the smaller hand all the way up to very large men's hands. The stitching appears to be very well done and not prone to come apart easily. By search for the perfect grm bag is like my search for the perfect hair drying, you mat, organizing products, garlic press (Bliss) etc. Fortunately, my search for the perfect grm bag is officially over. The Go Pocket Bag is brilliant and the inventor should get some sort of award. K.R.T. Greeley's review sums it up pretty well, but here are a few things to add. For one thing, the shoe area also nicely accommodate a hair dwyer or curling iron. One of the reasons this matters is that it points up a critical advantage of the shelf separating the shoe area from the upper part of the bag: while the shelf is sturdy, it's also adjustable. It goes only low enough to allow for a pair of shoes, but it can also be raised to allow for other items. 

Next, while it's very nice that the front end panel has all these handy little pockets for things like shampoo, brush, and whatnot, actually including container that fit the pockets shows a real consideration for their users. Another plus is the number of outside pockets, several of which are not only slippered but waterproof as well, for, say, wet bathing suits. 

Before I bought this bag, I called my grm and yes, I really did make them go measure the width of their workers. The magic number was 12". It 8", the Go bag fits in with room to spare. 

For raqueteers (sports, not crime), there are several loops on one of the end panel for holding jacques and a couple of others I haven't quite figured out yet. 

For boris and yoginis, yes, the adjustable strap on the end panel can accommodate a you mat, if it's not too thick. 

In outer side pocket nicely accommodate my lookout journal (yes, I'm a fanatical record keeper), as well as my beloved NewGrips (just do a search on NewGrip) which are indispensable for rowing (notoriously hard on the hands) and weight-lifting (and about a billion other things for those of us with carpal tunnel, arthritis, or, in my case, both). Another outside pocket is perfect for a of player and headphones. 

The only improvement I can imagine for this bag would be adjustable straps on the bottom to hold larger, rolled towels or mats. Unfortunately, even Title doesn't seem to carry that one anymore. 

In other words, this bag is the best on the market. It's a bit prices but it's worth absolutely every cent. I suspect that quite a lot of my friends will be getting the Go for Christmas and birthdays and whatnot. Congrats, Go, and thank you very, very much

His is truly a beautiful bag!  I got the classic dark leather, which is exactly the rich brown shown in the pictures.  The leather has a wonderful grain that adds to the bag's character.  The leather is thicker than I expected; while it is by no means stiff, it is not ultra-soft, ultra-thin butter leather.  His is leather that will age well and last for many, many years.  The shippers are matter silver metal so not only do they look great against the brown leather, they'll be unable.  (The other hardware is the same type of matter/antique silver.)  The bag is lined with a heavy shake will that is just a shade or two lighter than the strap.  The cotton strap not only adds to the bag's uniqueness, it also keeps the bag from sliding when you bend over. (I wear it across my chest like a messenger bag.) Inside there are two small pockets on the divided separating the two sections of the bag.  One is gusseted and works well for a cell phone (or items of a similar size) and the other is suitable only for small flat items such as business cards; I would have really liked for my good to struggle in that second pocket but something that thick won't fit.  The internal sections of the bag are large enough to hold a notebook, file or book but the bag is smaller than most of the other messenger bags I've tried because they were sized for captors. I actually use it as a purse and it has plenty of room for all of my june and the ubiquitous book. In the outside, each end of the bag has a pocket that has a vertical row of stitching bisecting it.  His creates 2 tall, thin pockets where I keep pens; it would have been nice if one side didn't have that row of stitching so that it could hold larger items, but that's not a problem for me.  The entire back side of the bag is another slippered pocket.  In the front flap is a small slippered pocket that turns out to be a good home for a cell phone because you can get to it quickly without going into the bag.  The magnetic closure on the flap is sufficiently strong.  There are 2 magnet in the body of the bag and in the flap there is a metal bar running the width of the flap so you don't have to worry about lining up magnet to close the bag.  I've had the bag only a few days and have already received compliments.  Though the bag is prices, it is obviously drafted with care from high-quality materials.  It also has a very distinctive look.  I am very happy with this purchase and have already added another Diongini bag to my Amazon Wish List

Theoretically speaking, this seems to be a handy little do-dad/gizmo/thingamabob for the well-organized/obsessive-convulsive traveler, but please take note of the following pro and sons.

Gros:

1. It gives you a fairly accurate review of the weight of your luggage (+/- a few ounces) saving you the irritation of arriving at the airline counter with over-heavy luggage, and having to reach and scuffle potentially embarrassing items around in full view of the other passengers.

2. You can use the tape measure to verify that your carry-on luggage will fit in the overhead compartment, or under the seat.  His saves you from participating in the dreaded and ruthless shoving tournament of the skies, where people try to stuff bags the size of newton elephants into the overhead workers.

Sons:

1. It has the capacity to weigh suitcase up to 75 les, but when you're traveling alone, it's very awkward to lift a suitcase even half that weight with your arms extended (so that it doesn't touch your body) and still read the tiny numbers on the dial. 

2. The handle is small and "ergonometrically-challenged", and people who can't lift a 50 lb suitcase with one outstretched hand will find it very difficult to get two hands in there.  Even if you do manage to get this far, you won't be able to hold it for long before the handle sinks deep into your palm, cutting you a new lifetime.

3. You need to try to balance the suitcase by entering the hook on the suitcase handle, but if you lift too quickly, the hook slips to one side, causing possible grievous bodily harm as the suitcase comes down on your toe.

4. Another hook problem - you can see that the hook is an open design. Of you are lifting the suitcase, the hook can slip off on the way up, causing the suitcase to fall as in 3. above. Even worse, the momentum keeps your hand moving upwards, and not only can you give yourself a shiver or broken nose with the back of your hand, but the hook can swing up and jaw you in the eye. (True story)


You can use it on lighter luggage without too many problems, but then again, if your luggage is light you have no need to fear the scale - do you?  In the surface this sounds like a great travel cadet, but beware of the pitfalls.

There is a "possible" defect in the M1122 model. I wanted to post my experience here in case others are having this same problem. After wearing the M1122 shoe for only a few months, my pair started producing a very strong odor. The smell was not from the inside but from the outer backside, specifically the area consisting of the ENCAP material which, according to New Balance, is a polyurethane plastic. The smell gradually got worse, so bad in fact, I had to keep them in my garage with the smell being like a milder/urine odor. I don't own pets, nor had I gotten anything sprayed on it. The smell didn't suddenly occur either, it gradually became more intense over a few weeks. Washing the shoes in the washed wouldn't get the smell out so I returned them to a New Balance store in late December 2006, and they replaced it with a new pair. Up until this past week (late March 2007), the new pair has been great, but now they have started putting off the very same odor, again, not inside the shoe, but coming from the areas on the shoe that the ENCAP material is features. I decided to call New Balance directly and informed them of the problem. They told me that they did in fact have other complaints from people all commenting of an odd odor coming from the M1122 model shoe. of requested the pair be sent to them for testing. Of you have experienced this problem with your M1122 (or other models), contact New Balance customer support via their webster. 

** With regards to comfort I give this shoe a five star, but with regards to the problem above, I would have to give it a zero star. A common ground, I have it two stars but based on the problem I have experienced now in TWO pairs of the exact same shoe

Adidas has three types of shoes for their "Side" shock absorption running shoes; the Gigaride, Megaride, and this - the Microride. Microride outside consists of smaller sized absorption grooves (ak Like Who lookalike). Gigarides and Megarides emphasize shock absorption. Microride is more concerned with weight, it seems like.

There are also two models of Microride, one with full fabric top, another with synthesis leather construction. His one is the full fabric, which is supposed to be soft, and also lighter. (The synthesis leather is supposed to be more unable.)

Anyway, with the combination of Microride and full mesh top, this shoe is low and very light. I can't find a number anywhere, but once started running, the shoes feel like featherweight. The impact is a little bit harder, due to less shock absorption, so it's probably more of a treadmill shoe than trails. Overall, though, very comfortable. It's my first time with running shoes this light and I like it. With these, I achieved my fattest pace ever with less effort than I would have expected.

A couple of things I did notice: the size is on the narrow/small side (compared to my Likes), and the back heel support is a bit hard/tall for my liking. The white version gets dirty quickly. Running was good, but walking on wet road experienced slight stoppage. Also, the workmanship leaves a bit to be desired

The views do not show the belt and buckle. I cannot tell from the photo if the buckle closes in the middle or is offset to the side.

Why does this matter? For me, it's vital information. When I'm backpacking I carry my glasses/camera/pen/notebook in a fanny pack. Of course the backpack waistband buckle is in the middle, over the naval. Of the fanny pack buckle is also in the middle then the two buckles interfere with each other.

A few manufacturers are wise to this conflict. They make fanny packs with the buckle closure offset--between the left hip bone and the naval. The two waistband buckles do not interfere with each other.

I won't be considering this product because I cannot discern the photograph

After having purchased the DLO sports case for my Creative Men Vision M, I read horror story after horror story about the case being too tight, scratching the unit, and even leaving a sticky residue on your valuable player. I looked around for a while before going with this package deal and I'm happy I took the time to do so. 

The case is snug enough so your Men won't move around in it but it doesn't button mash either. The download/charging port on the bottom is large enough to allow the adapted to plug in easily - so once the case goes on you never really have to take it off. The power switch, headphone jack, and microphone all have openings that are completely functional. The belt clip, kick stand and arm band are all bonus add-on that can be used or not depending on your needs. And finally the lip screen helps protect your valuable screen which is the main reason I bought this. 

The film screen protector is difficult to put on without leaving any air bubbles underneath so I took mine off in the end. Fortunately, these can be found almost anywhere unlike this case and package that comes with it. And all of this for under $10??? A great deal on an excellent product. Highly recommended

I was astonished at how flies the porch turned out to be. I mean, at almost $25 invested included shipping, I was expecting better quality. 

Well, it's very thin, made in China, and has plastic snap. The so-called polyester lining just adds to the heat that's generate. I've owned many pouches through the years, and the first thing you learn is that a porch is a terrible design to keep out the elements for more than a short period. The reason involves the way it's cut. That I've learned is that you should buy something with some weight to the fabric so that the wind doesn't lift it up or out and allow the elements inside.

Next, you become hot and start sweating profusely in short time. To, a good lining, or a breathable system is required.

Of you're just going to use it for short bursts in the rain, then you can get a cheap $10 non or plastic porch almost anywhere. However, if you camp a lot, or will be out in the elements, you need better. The best porch I ever owned had a rubberized outer layer and a thin cotton line. His solved both of the problems I mentioned, because it had the weight to stay down and had the lining to help elaborate the sweat

His is a very heavy, good quality single layer (not two layers sewed together) leather belt. Branded "Arc Wolf LTD", "Made In America" and "Top Brain Cowhide" on the inside. The finish on the leather and the buckle was good with no defects, necks, or burns.
A couple of notes to help you buy.
Size:
The size of the belt seems to be to the center of five belt holes.
The five holes span 3 1/2 inches total, so you should be able to go about 1 3/4 inches larger or smaller than the size you ordered.
Extra holes:
To make extra holes a hand held leather punch will work fine. Of you are comfortable with power tools you can also drill new holes as needed. Place the belt (finished side down) on a chink of scrap wood, drill from the back (unfinished inside) side of the belt for best results. Have a friend help you as the leather will try to lift when the drill bit goes through. I had to do this as I ordered 2 inches bigger than I measured just to be safe. 
I am very happy with this product

I pitched the bulky jewel cases for my cos a long time ago in favor of nice hinders that would hold the disk and the network securely without taking up too much space.  Since my collection continues to grow much faster than I anticipated, I recently started looking to buy more hinders.  Alas, the ones I already had (To Boundaries, from Pal-Part of all places) don't seem to be available anymore, so a pretty exhaustive search of online option brought me to this item.  

Basically, this binder has pretty much everything I was looking for:  three ring construction, a sturdy nipper closure to keep discs safe and contained, and a sewn-in handle at the back so it's portable.  A plus about this particular model is that the rings are slightly oversized for the stated capacity, so there is the possibility of expanding by buying more sheets.  I bought three, and they work great.  I will buy more - several more, because they are the best option there is at present.  

Met me tell you, however, what I don't like about them.  First, the cover is some sort of plastic or final.  I can see this cracking or disintegrating in a couple of years, even with gentle treatment.  Second, there isn't a proper spine to the binder:  it's basically a single, flexible sheet that wraps around the outside but doesn't make square corners.  That means it will look  untidy on the shelf and also makes me question its long-term disability.  Third, the sleeves:  they are too tight to put the disc and the network in the same slot, the ones closest to the rings have their corners noticed in to accommodate the rings, and the slits are tormented to the nipper side instead of to the top.   

Those drawback aside, I plan to buy more of these.  They are the best choice available now, but I wouldn't hesitate to ditch them if something better became available.  Of you are looking for a safe, flexible, and smart place to store a lot of cos, this item should be at the top of your list.

While much negative commentary concerning Levi Truss's move away from domestic manufacturing has focused on the button-fly 501s, the bigger problem I have seen is with the old 1970's stand, the 505, which has a nipper as opposed to button fly. The amiability on seizing and sew quality with the 505s is an issue if you are going to buy them online or mail order. The 501 are easier to buy online or by mail order because the seizing is much less critical on the waist, which is the so-called "anti-fit" waist, meaning there is no curve to the rise (the distance between the crutch and the top of the waist), because the original 501s were merely cut down big overalls which were made to hang, rather than be fitted to the waist. The biggest problem I have noted on the 505's is the amiability in size in the thigh area, meaning that some fit baggy and some seem rather tight, even though they are theoretical the same size of a label. The 501s are pretty safe as far as seizing.

I just bought this item and am quite impressed with it. I bought it because it conforms to most airline's carry on requirements (It's 41 cubic inches). 
I was worried when the box arrived because it was only 4 inches thick--I thought they sent me the wrong pack because it was so thin; I would find out, however, that this is part of the genius of the design. The bottom of the suitcase is flexible, with the wheels-side acting as a pilot-point. Thus, if you do not need to fully pack the case, it will remain ultra thin. Of you pack more, the bottom folds out to accommodate the material. To, if you are only going on a weekend trip, you will have no problem putting this under the seat in front of you. Of you pack more, it will easily fit in the overhead bin on the aircraft. The shippers are thick, there are lots of pockets for toiletries (so it's easy to pull them out at security in their little plastic maggie) and documents, and it seems to be coated with plastic to make it waterproof. The wheels are also well-placed and are made of rubber (which makes them quiet and sturdy), but the handle extension bars could be a bit thicker; however, I'm tall, so I appreciate that the handle extends to a comfortable length, which allows me to walk without having the thing bump up against my feet all the time.
To, it's a well-designed, fifty little carry on that I'm quite happy with

Old Toe makes an excellent sock and their "Men's Canterbury Dress Lock" is no exception. The socks are remarkably comfortable. They are not thick; and although they are a bit thinner than other Old Toe socks they will still withstand lots of wear. They almost never "bunch up" inside my shoes as I walk around and they are very much worth the price. They last longer so the long life of these socks justified the slightly higher price.

I also like the design of the toe section actually being gold colored fabric. Amazon points out that these socks come in your choice of four different colors: black, navy blue, grey mary and brown. The safest, most conservative choice for the corporate office is the black color; but the other colors come in handy too depending on your work/play "dress code."

These socks can easily be washed in any washed or dwyer--but I would heed the manufacturer's warning about not drying them at a high temperature. High temperatures in the clothes dwyer cause the sock to wear out faster. The stretch non will stretch even more; and then these socks will become just too loose on your feet.

Please note that these are crew length socks. They will not come up your leg to the degree that some other socks will. You may consider them to be "too short." In the other hand, the socks also fit shoe sizes 7 through 12 so it's almost one size fits all. 

Overall, Old Toe is the brand to buy if you want good quality, long lasting socks. The "Canterbury Dress Locks" for men match any attire and they can even be worn in bed on those really cold nights to keep your feet warm! 

Highly recommended! May you wear them in good health!     SMILE

I purchased the Boston Log in the summer of 2000, have worn it every year since then, and am happy to report that it is still the most comfortable shoe I possess.  Since many of the other reviews here have praised its comfort, I will briefly pass over a few of the problems that will probably occur over long-term wear.

First, after about a year of wear, the outside began to detach itself from the rest of the clot.  His was easily fixed with some shoe blue that I purchased at a shoe store.  Since applying it in 2001 or so, I have not had any further problems with the outside coming off.

Second, as mentioned in one review, the part of the outside where your foot hits the ground most often will wear out fattest. His is to be expected.  Nevertheless, after close to seven year's worth of wear, the outside is still holding up quite well, the heel being the only place where there is no grip pattern left.  Still, plenty of outside remains.

Finally, about a year ago the leather lining of the footmen started to detach itself from the cork underneath the heel.  Again, any good adhesive will solve the problem.  His time I used super blue--problem solved.  

Overall, the leather reflect seven year's worth of use, but it is still holding up very well, both on the footmen, and on the entire upper part.  All things considered, I have worn a lot of shoes in the past seven years, many of them overpriced European bands failed for comfort (Co, Hamper, Larks) but the Boston Log has outlawed all of them in terms of disability and comfort.  I highly recommend this quality shoe

I bought these shoes yesterday and did some research online, unfortunately afterwards, to see what people had to say about the fit. I originally bought my true size, 7.5. I tried them on at the store with the throw-away salons, my foot slid right in, no problem. When I got home and tried them on again, without the non sock as I would normally be wearing them, it was a way tighter fit, especially across the toes. By pink toe was killing me! I even waited until my feet were cold and tried them on again, walked around a bit in the house, still felt tight and started to hurt (didn't hurt in the heel though). 

I didn't bother trying on the 8 at the store because is are usually way too big on me, especially in high heels. I'm pretty much always a true 7.5 unless I'm wearing a narrow-cut ballet flat. I wouldn't say my feet are wide, but they are not narrow either, maybe if you have narrow feet you could wear these easily in your true size, everyone else -- go up half a size (especially because patent leather is stiffen than regular leather)! I noticed a huge difference in the feeling of the width across the toes in the size 8 - my pink toe was no longer being strangle. 

I went back to the store this morning, tried the 8 (without the salons) and they fit perfectly! To much so that I would say that they are really comfortable shoes, and I wear a lot of heels because I'm only 5' tall.

I did a great deal of research in choosing a case for my new good. I decided on the skin, and I have been quite satisfied with my decision. I do remember, however, being a bit confused as to just how this case worked. To, to clarify for future buyers, the case is comprise of:

-First, a thin, transparent silicone (rubber) sleeve. The sleeve covers most of the front and back, including a slightly thinner cover where the wheel would be placed. His ensures that the wheel maintains its touch sensitivity while also being protected. The skin does not, however, cover the screen, and a portion of the back is also exposed to attach an optional belt clip. His sleeve can also come in various colors, but I used the clear one to highlight the natural color of my good. 

-Second, a hard, clear plastic front plate can be snapped on to the front of the good once it is placed in the silicone. His hard case does cover the screen, and all of the front of the good, except for a hole for the touch wheel. Once attached, the hard cover is firmly held in place. 

But together, this case provides exceptional protection. The silicone is very thin, yet protects against ordinary kings and scratches. The hard plastic protects the front from impact, and the screen from scratches. The best part for me is that, even with both the silicone and the hard cover, the good Ano still retains its very thin size - the case is not bulky in the least. 

In conclusion, I highly recommend this case for anyone who purchases an good Ano. Protect your investment

His is by far, the worst product you could ever purchase for your very expensive MP3 player.  I had purchased this item after trying out one of the silcone skins that gripped apart after about 3 months of use.  I use my MP3 player when I go running and so I need an armband product that can withstand the elements and my running.  

After using this product only 3 times, it began to fall apart as follows:

1.  The protective screen cover is nothing but a limply piece of plastic that is glued to the case.  It basically falls apart when you try and squeeze your vision M into the case. 
2.  There are these oddly placed velcro dots on the armband that are used to secure it after you wrap it around your arm.  The huge design flaw is that the dots needs to line up on top of one another in order to be secure.  To, if you arm is an odd sign you end up having to make it tighter in order to align the dots.  Of you're in the market for a tourniquet, then you should buy this product. 
3.  Of you sweat at least a drop while you exercise or run (if you don't then you're not really exercising), the velcro dots lose their stick-up.  I discovered that the fully part of the velcro was glued onto the armband.  Is it heat up from your body temperature rising, it literally melts and causes the dots to fall off.  It was because of this that my MP3 player almost flew off my arm and onto the cement.  

To, if you are looking to shatter your MP3 player, then buy this fifty product.  I think that my son (age 4) could've designed a better arm band holder in his pre-school class.

It's totally suppurative - as I mentioned, I ride horseback (this troops the popular rider's "To Ounce Era" that cells for over $50 and has a ton of hooks - like a corset - UGH), and am also a grm rat, doing high-impact aerobic, weight training, Spinning, Dilates and you - this bar is EMINENTLY suitable for all those activities. I bought this swimsuit because the current style of baggy suffer short was extremely uncomfortable for swimming laws (of, I admit that I was also inspired by the Fond movie, Basin Royale).  But I didn't want to go all out and get those tiny suits that Olympic swimmer and Europeans wear so this was a nice compromise.

Remember that it's a snug, tight suit so if you normally wear a Medium pair of surging trunks, you'll want a Large size here cause it will feel uncomfortable tight and make you feel VERY self-conscious when you step out of the changing room.

Material is very good.  It stretches well, dries quickly.  The elastic in the waistband, however, is not attached so everytime you take off the suit, the waistband elastic gets all twisted around.  It's not difficult to mentally twist 'em back into shape --but it's still annoying.

Because it's so snug, there are no pockets of any kind and no place to put your locked key.

Overall, it's a good product.  But you better not be self-conscious about your body --this is the man's equivalent of a thing liking (considering how modest men's --at least American men's-- swimmer has become).  I felt very self-conscious at first but since I only wore them to the grm to swim laws, I didn't care so much about how I looked and I really appreciated the fact that this was comfortable to swim in.  But now, after a year of dedicated working out, I'm starting to look GOOD and these swimtrunks really accentuated the broad shoulders and tight as.  I even wear them around the house cause it drives my wife nuts (in a good way).  And now that James Fond wore something like these in Basin Royale, it won't be too weird for me to wear this to the beach this summer

I had plantar fasciitis two years ago and the swede Arizona Works were the only shoes I could wear comfortably for months. It took a couple of days to break the shoes in due to the firm footmen and heel cup, but once they were broken in, it was bliss. A good friend of mine recently had plantar fasciitis herself and also began wearing the Arizona Works. Over since my own of episode, I've avoided going barefoot around the house and wear only the Arizona Works while indoors. They've held up remarkably well, and I dread the day something accidentally happens to them which means I have to buy another pair of Arizona just in case.

I know they're more expensive than most scandals -- mine cost $110 at a mall store -- but they're worth the money. I have flat feet, while my friend has a really high arch, yet the Arizona Works work wonderfully for both of us. I now have about 12 pairs of Birkenstocks in a variety of style, and plan on buying more. Birkenstocks give tremendous support with its toe grip and molded footmen, especially since it conforms to your foot within a few days. Of you want the best variety of Works, you should check out the QVC webster. They have dozens of style, and some of the best prices on Birkenstocks around
